column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: The theory of the photoelectric effect must explain the experimental observations of the emission of electrons from an illuminated metal surface .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: For a given metal , there exists a certain minimum frequency of incident radiation below which no photoelectrons are emitted .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: This frequency is called the " threshold frequency " .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: Increasing the frequency of the incident beam , keeping the number of incident photons fixed ( this would result in a proportionate increase in energy ) increases the maximum kinetic energy of the photoelectrons emitted .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: Thus the stopping voltage increases .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: The number of electrons also changes because the probability that each photon results in an emitted electron is a function of photon energy .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: If the intensity of the incident radiation is increased , there is no effect on the kinetic energies of the photoelectrons .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: Above the threshold frequency , the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted photoelectron depends on the frequency of the incident light , but is independent of the intensity of the incident light so long as the latter is not too high .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: For a given metal and frequency of incident radiation , the rate at which photoelectrons are ejected is directly proportional to the intensity of the incident light .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: Increase in intensity of incident beam ( keeping the frequency fixed ) increases the magnitude of the photoelectric current , though stopping voltage remains the same .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: The time lag between the incidence of radiation and the emission of a photoelectron is very small , less than 10−9 second .

column1: Why does the quantity of electrons change as an aftereffect of photoelectric outflow ?
column2: The direction of distribution of emitted electrons peaks in the direction of polarization ( the direction of the electric field ) of the incident light , if it is linearly polarized .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Research over the past few decades has shown that the nutrients and minerals in seafood can make improvements in brain development and reproduction and has highlighted the role for seafood in the functions of the human body .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Doctors have known of strong links between fish and healthy hearts ever since they noticed that fish - eating Inuit populations in the Arctic had low levels of heart disease .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: One study has suggested that adding one portion of fish a week to your diet can cut your chances of suffering a heart attack by half .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Fish is thought to protect the heart because eating less saturated fat and more Omega-3 can help to lower the amount of cholesterol and triglycerides in the blood – two fats that , in excess , increase the risk of heart disease .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Omega-3 fats also have natural built - in anti-oxidants , which are thought to stop the thickening and damaging of artery walls .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Regularly eating fish oils is also thought to reduce the risk of arrhythmia – irregular electrical activity in the heart which increases the risk of sudden heart attacks.10-12 % of the human brain is composed of lipids , including the Omega-3 fat DHA .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Recent studies suggest that older people can boost their brain power by eating more oily fish , what with regular consumers being able to remember better and think faster than those who do n't consume at all .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Other research has also suggested that adding more DHA to the diet of children with attention - deficit hyperactivity disorder can reduce their behavioural problems and improve their reading skills , while there have also been links suggested between DHA and better concentration .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Separate studies have suggested that older people who eat fish at least once a week could also have a lower chance of developing dementia and Alzheimer 's disease .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Including fish as a regular part of a balanced diet has been shown to help the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis – a painful condition that causes joints to swell up , reducing strength and mobility .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Studies also show that sufferers feel less stiff and sore in the morning if they keep their fish oil intake topped up .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Recent research has also found a link between Omega-3 fats and a slowing down in the wearing of cartilage that leads to osteoarthritis , opening the door for more research into whether eating more fish could help prevent the disease .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Fish is high in minerals such as zinc , iodine and selenium , which keep the body running smoothly .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Iodine is essential for the thyroid gland , which controls growth and metabolism , while selenium is used to make enzymes that protect cell walls from cancer - causing free radicals , and helps prevent DNA damage caused by radiation and some chemicals .

column1: Name some benefits for older people eating oily fish .
column2: Fish is also a source of vitamin A , which is needed for healthy skin and eyes , and vitamin D , which is needed to help the body absorb calcium to strengthen teeth and bones .

column1: Which Coast Guard veteran is featured in The Invisible War ?
column2: The Invisible War  features interviews with veterans from multiple branches of the United States Armed Forces who recount the events surrounding their assaults .

column1: Which Coast Guard veteran is featured in The Invisible War ?
column2: Their stories show many common themes , such as the lack of recourse to an impartial justice system , reprisals against survivors instead of against perpetrators , the absence of adequate emotional and physical care for survivors , the unhindered advancement of perpetrators ' careers , and the forced expulsion of survivors from service .

column1: Which Coast Guard veteran is featured in The Invisible War ?
column2: Interspersed with these first person testimonies are interviews with advocates , journalists , mental health professionals , active duty and retired generals , Department of Defense officials , and members of the military justice system .

column1: Which Coast Guard veteran is featured in The Invisible War ?
column2: The film also includes footage , often shot by the veterans themselves , which documents their lives and continuing struggles in the aftermath of their assaults .

column1: Which Coast Guard veteran is featured in The Invisible War ?
column2: In the film 's most prominent narrative , Coast Guard veteran Seaman Kori Cioca struggles to earn benefits from the Department of Veterans Affairs to pay for the many medical difficulties that have resulted from her rape .

column1: Which Coast Guard veteran is featured in The Invisible War ?
column2: With the help of attorney Susan L. Burke , Cioca , along with other survivors featured in the film , brings a civil suit against the Department of Defense alleging a failure to adequately address sexual assault within the military .

column1: Which Coast Guard veteran is featured in The Invisible War ?
column2: Other past incidents of sexual abuse recounted in the film include the 1991 Navy Tailhook scandal , the 1996 Army Aberdeen scandal , and the 2003 Air Force Academy scandal .

column1: Which Coast Guard veteran is featured in The Invisible War ?
column2: The Invisible War  uses these examples to argue that the military has consistently made empty promises to address its high rate of sexual assault .

column1: Which Coast Guard veteran is featured in The Invisible War ?
column2: These stories culminate with an examination of the previously unreported culture of sexual harassment and sexual assault at the prestigious Marine Barracks Washington .

column1: Which Coast Guard veteran is featured in The Invisible War ?
column2: The survivors and advocates featured in the film call for changes to the way the military handles sexual assault , such as shifting prosecution away from unit commanders , who often are either friends with assailants or are assailants themselves .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: Shooting is the act of attempting to score points by throwing the ball through the basket , methods varying with players and situations .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: Typically , a player faces the basket with both feet facing the basket .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: A player will rest the ball on the fingertips of the dominant hand ( the shooting arm ) slightly above the head , with the other hand supporting the side of the ball .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: The ball is usually shot by jumping ( though not always ) and extending the shooting arm .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: The shooting arm , fully extended with the wrist fully bent , is held stationary for a moment following the release of the ball , known as a " follow - through " .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: Players often try to put a steady backspin on the ball to absorb its impact with the rim .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: The ideal trajectory of the shot is somewhat controversial , but generally a proper arc is recommended .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: Players may shoot directly into the basket or may use the backboard to redirect the ball into the basket .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: The two most common shots that use the above described setup are the " set - shot " and the " jump - shot " .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: The set - shot is taken from a standing position , with neither foot leaving the floor , typically used for free throws , and in other circumstances whilst the jump - shot is taken in mid-air , the ball released near the top of the jump .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: This provides much greater power and range , and it also allows the player to elevate over the defender .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: Failure to release the ball before the feet return to the floor is considered a traveling violation .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: Another common shot is called the " lay - up " .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: This shot requires the player to be in motion toward the basket , and to " lay " the ball " up " and into the basket , typically off the backboard ( the backboard - free , underhand version is called a " finger roll " ) .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: The most crowd - pleasing and typically highest - percentage accuracy shot is the " slam dunk " , in which the player jumps very high and throws the ball downward , through the basket whilst touching it .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: Another shot that is becoming common is the " circus shot " .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: The circus shot is a low - percentage shot that is flipped , heaved , scooped , or flung toward the hoop while the shooter is off - balance , airborne , falling down , and / or facing away from the basket .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: A back - shot is a shot taken when the player is facing away from the basket , and may be shot with the dominant hand , or both ; but there is a very low chance that the shot will be successful .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: A shot that misses both the rim and the backboard completely is referred to as an " air - ball " .

column1: In basketball , what is a brick ?
column2: A particularly bad shot , or one that only hits the backboard , is jocularly called a brick .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: Astronomy is a natural science that is the study of celestial objects ( such as moons , planets , stars , nebulae , and galaxies ) , the physics , chemistry , and evolution of such objects , and phenomena that originate outside the atmosphere of Earth , including supernovae explosions , gamma ray bursts , and cosmic background radiation .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: A related but distinct subject , cosmology , is concerned with studying the universe as a whole .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: Astronomy is one of the oldest sciences .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: Prehistoric cultures have left astronomical artifacts such as the Egyptian monuments and Nubian monuments , and early civilizations such as the Babylonians , Greeks , Chinese , Indians , Iranians and Maya performed methodical observations of the night sky .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: However , the invention of the telescope was required before astronomy was able to develop into a modern science .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: Historically , astronomy has included disciplines as diverse as astrometry , celestial navigation , observational astronomy , and the making of calendars , but professional astronomy is nowadays often considered to be synonymous with astrophysics .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: During the 20th century , the field of professional astronomy split into observational and theoretical branches .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: Observational astronomy is focused on acquiring data from observations of astronomical objects , which is then analyzed using basic principles of physics .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: Theoretical astronomy is oriented toward the development of computer or analytical models to describe astronomical objects and phenomena .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: The two fields complement each other , with theoretical astronomy seeking to explain the observational results and observations being used to confirm theoretical results .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: Astronomy is one of the few sciences where amateurs can still play an active role , especially in the discovery and observation of transient phenomena .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: Amateur astronomers have contributed to many important astronomical discoveries .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: Astronomy is not to be confused with astrology , the belief system which claims that human affairs are correlated with the positions of celestial objects .

column1: How are astronomy and cosmology different ?
column2: Although the two fields share a common origin they are now entirely distinct .

column1: In what way is an inosine read as ?

column1: In what way is an inosine read as ?

column1: In what way is an inosine read as ?

column1: In what way is an inosine read as ?

column1: In what way is an inosine read as ?

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Different cancers respond differently to radiation therapy .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The response of a cancer to radiation is described by its radiosensitivity .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Highly radiosensitive cancer cells are rapidly killed by modest doses of radiation .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: These include leukemias , most lymphomas and germ cell tumors .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The majority of epithelial cancers are only moderately radiosensitive , and require a significantly higher dose of radiation ( 60-70 Gy ) to achieve a radical cure .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Some types of cancer are notably radioresistant , that is , much higher doses are required to produce a radical cure than may be safe in clinical practice .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Renal cell cancer and melanoma are generally considered to be radioresistant .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: It is important to distinguish the radiosensitivity of a particular tumor , which to some extent is a laboratory measure , from the radiation " curability " of a cancer in actual clinical practice .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: For example , leukemias are not generally curable with radiation therapy , because they are disseminated through the body .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Lymphoma may be radically curable if it is localised to one area of the body .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Similarly , many of the common , moderately radioresponsive tumors are routinely treated with curative doses of radiation therapy if they are at an early stage .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: For example : non-melanoma skin cancer , head and neck cancer , breast cancer , non-small cell lung cancer , cervical cancer , anal cancer , prostate cancer .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Metastatic cancers are generally incurable with radiation therapy because it is not possible to treat the whole body .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Before treatment , a CT scan is often performed to identify the tumor and surrounding normal structures .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The patient is then sent for a simulation so that molds can be created to be used during treatment .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The patient receives small skin marks to guide the placement of treatment fields .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The response of a tumor to radiation therapy is also related to its size .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: For complex reasons , very large tumors respond less well to radiation than smaller tumors or microscopic disease .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Various strategies are used to overcome this effect .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The most common technique is surgical resection prior to radiation therapy .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: This is most commonly seen in the treatment of breast cancer with wide local excision or mastectomy followed by adjuvant radiation therapy .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Another method is to shrink the tumor with neoadjuvant chemotherapy prior to radical radiation therapy .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: A third technique is to enhance the radiosensitivity of the cancer by giving certain drugs during a course of radiation therapy .

column1: What are some examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Examples of radiosensiting drugs include : Cisplatin , Nimorazole , and Cetuximab .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: The Peking Roast Duck that came to be associated with the term was fully developed during the later Ming Dynasty , and by then , Peking Duck was one of the main dishes on imperial court menus .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: The first restaurant specialising in Peking Duck , Bianyifang , was established in the Xianyukou , Qianmen area of Beijing in 1416 .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: For instance , one of the verses of " Duan Zhu Zhi Ci " , a collection of Beijing poems was , " Fill your plates with roast duck and suckling pig " .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: In 1864 , the Quanjude ( 全聚德 ) restaurant was established in Beijing .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: Yang Quanren ( 楊全仁 ) , the founder of Quanjude , developed the hung oven to roast ducks .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: With its innovations and efficient management , the restaurant became well known in China , introducing the Peking Duck to the rest of the world .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: By the mid-20th century , Peking Duck had become a national symbol of China , favored by tourists and diplomats alike .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: For example , Henry Kissinger , the Secretary of State of the United States , met Premier Zhou Enlai in the Great Hall of the People on July 10 , during his first visit to China .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: After a round of inconclusive talks in the morning , the delegation was served Peking Duck for lunch , which became Kissinger 's favourite .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: The Americans and Chinese issued a joint statement the following day , inviting President Richard Nixon to visit China in 1972 .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: Peking Duck was hence considered one of the factors behind the rapprochement of the United States to China in the 1970s .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: Following Zhou 's death in 1976 , Kissinger paid another visit to Beijing to savor Peking Duck .

column1: When did duck roasting begin in China ?
column2: Peking Duck , at the Quanjude in particular , has also been a favorite dish for various political leaders ranging from Cuban revolutionary Fidel Castro to former German chancellor Helmut Kohl .

column1: What is SOLAS ?

column1: What is SOLAS ?

"

column1: What is SOLAS ?

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?
column2: The recognition and acceptance afforded to Mendeleev 's table came from two decisions he made .

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?
column2: The first was to leave gaps in the table when it seemed that the corresponding element had not yet been discovered .

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?
column2: Mendeleev was not the first chemist to do so , but he was the first to be recognized as using the trends in his periodic table to predict the properties of those missing elements , such as gallium and germanium .

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?
column2: The second decision was to occasionally ignore the order suggested by the atomic weights and switch adjacent elements , such as tellurium and iodine , to better classify them into chemical families .

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?
column2: With the development of theories of atomic structure , it became apparent that Mendeleev had unintentionally listed the elements in order of increasing atomic number or nuclear charge .

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?
column2: The significance of atomic numbers to the organization of the periodic table was not appreciated until the existence and properties of protons and neutrons became understood .

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?
column2: Mendeleev 's periodic tables used atomic weight instead of atomic number to organize the elements , information determinable to fair precision in his time .

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?
column2: Atomic weight worked well enough in most cases to ( as noted ) give a presentation that was able to predict the properties of missing elements more accurately than any other method then known .

column1: What year did an extended version of Meyer 's table appear ?
column2: Substitution of atomic numbers , once understood , gave a definitive , integer - based sequence for the elements , still used today even as new synthetic elements are being produced and studied .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: Both German and Soviet casualties during the battle of Moscow have been a subject of debate , as various sources provide somewhat different estimates .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: Not all historians agree on what should be considered the " Battle of Moscow " in the timeline of World War II .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: While the start of the battle is usually regarded as the beginning of Operation " Typhoon " on 30 September 1941 ( or sometimes on 2 October 1941 ) , there are two different dates for the end of the offensive .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: In particular , some sources ( such as Erickson and Glantz ) exclude the Rzhev offensive from the scope of the battle , considering it as a distinct operation and making the Moscow offensive " stop " on 7 January 1942 — thus lowering the number of casualties .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: Other historians , who include the Rzhev and Vyazma operations in the scope of the battle ( thus making the battle end in May 1942 ) , give higher casualty numbers .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: There are also significant differences in figures from various sources .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: John Erickson , in his " Barbarossa : The Axis and the Allies " , gives a figure of 653,924 Soviet casualties between October 1941 and January 1942 .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: Glantz , in his book " When Titans Clashed " , gives a figure of 658,279 for the defense phase alone , plus 370,955 for the winter counteroffensive until 7 January 1942 .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: The estimate of 400,000 German casualties by January 1942 reported in the " Great Soviet Encyclopedia " , published in 1973–1978 , is clearly inflated .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: A much more accurate estimate is provided in the " Moscow Encyclopedia " , published in 1997 ; its authors , based on various sources , give a figure of 145,000 German and 900,000 Soviet casualties for the defensive phase , along with 103,000 German and 380,000 Soviet casualties for the counteroffensive until 7 January 1942 .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: Many of the Soviet casualties , however , consisted of captured men .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: On the other hand , Wehrmacht daily casualty reports show 35,757 killed in action , 128,716 wounded , and 9,721 missing in action for the entire Army Group Center between 1 October 1941 and 10 January 1942 .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: Therefore , total casualties between 30 September 1941 , and 7 January 1942 , are estimated to be between 174,000 and 248,000 for the " Wehrmacht " ( Wehrmacht reports / Moscow encyclopedia estimate ) and between 650,000 and 1,280,000 for the Red Army ( Erickson / Moscow encyclopedia estimate ) .

column1: What was the estimated total of casualties ?
column2: Regardless of these disagreements , the Battle of Moscow is considered among the most lethal battles in world history .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: Before boarding a plane to fly to Indianapolis for one last campaign speech in a predominantly black neighborhood of the city he learned that Martin Luther King had been shot , leading Kennedy press secretary Frank Mankiewicz to suggest that he ask the audience to pray for the King family and ask them to follow King 's deeply held belief in non-violence .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: They did not learn that King was dead until they landed in Indianapolis .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: Both Mankiewicz and speechwriter Adam Walinsky drafted notes immediately before the rally for Kennedy 's use , but Kennedy refused Walinsky 's notes , instead using some that he had likely written on the ride over ; Mankiewicz arrived after Kennedy had already begun to speak .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: Prior to arriving at the rally , the Chief of Police in Indianapolis told Kennedy that he could not provide protection and that giving the remarks would be too dangerous , but Kennedy decided to go ahead regardless .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: Standing on a podium mounted on a flatbed truck , Kennedy spoke for just four minutes and fifty - seven seconds .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: Robert F. Kennedy was the first to inform the audience of the death of Martin Luther King , causing some in the audience to scream and wail .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: Several of Kennedy 's aides were even worried that the delivery of this information would result in a riot .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: Once the audience quieted down , Kennedy acknowledged that many in the audience would be filled with anger .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: But then Kennedy went on : " For those of you who are black and are tempted to fill with -- be filled with hatred and mistrust of the injustice of such an act , against all white people , I would only say that I can also feel in my own heart the same kind of feeling .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: I had a member of my family killed , but he was killed by a white man . "

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: These remarks surprised Kennedy aides , who had never heard him speak publicly of John F. Kennedy 's death .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: Kennedy continued , saying that the country had to make an effort to " go beyond these rather difficult times , " and then quoted a poem by the Greek playwright Aeschylus , on the theme of the wisdom that comes , against one 's will , from pain .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: To conclude , Kennedy said that the country needed and wanted unity between blacks and whites , asked the audience members to pray for the King family and the country , and once more quoted the ancient Greeks .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?
column2: The speech was credited in part with preventing post-assassination rioting in Indianapolis where it was given , though there were riots in many other parts of the country .

column1: What was Kennedy campaigning for at the time ?

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?
column2: Woods are large - headed , long - shafted clubs meant to propel the ball a long distance from relatively " open " lies , such as the tee box and fairway .

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?
column2: Traditionally these clubs had heads made of a hardwood , hence the name , but virtually all modern woods are now made of metal such as titanium , or of composite materials .

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?
column2: Irons are shorter - shafted clubs with a metal head primarily consisting of a flat , angled striking face .

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?
column2: Traditionally the clubhead was forged from iron ; modern iron clubheads are investment - cast from a steel alloy .

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?
column2: The third class is the putter , which evolved from the irons to create a low - lofted , balanced club designed to roll the ball along the green and into the hole .

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?
column2: Putters are virtually always used on the green or in the surrounding rough / fringe .

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?
column2: A fourth class , called hybrids , evolved as a cross between woods and irons , and are typically seen replacing the low - lofted irons with a club that provides similar distance , but a higher launch angle and a more forgiving nature .

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?
column2: A maximum of 14 clubs is allowed in a player 's bag at one time during a stipulated round .

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?
column2: Golf balls are spherical , usually white ( although other colors are allowed ) , and minutely pock - marked by dimples that decrease aerodynamic drag by increasing air turbulence around the ball in motion , which delays " boundary layer " separation and reduces the drag - inducing " wake " behind the ball , thereby allowing the ball to fly farther .

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?

column1: In which manner is the golf club used ?

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: During the past century , astronomy has been revolutionized by the use of new methods for observing the universe .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: Astronomical observations were originally made using visible light .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: Galileo Galilei pioneered the use of telescopes to enhance these observations .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: However , visible light is only a small portion of the electromagnetic spectrum , and not all objects in the distant universe shine strongly in this particular band .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: More useful information may be found , for example , in radio wavelengths .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: Using radio telescopes , astronomers have found pulsars , quasars , and other extreme objects that push the limits of our understanding of physics .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: Observations in the microwave band have opened our eyes to the faint imprints of the Big Bang , a discovery Stephen Hawking called the " greatest discovery of the century , if not all time " .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: Similar advances in observations using gamma rays , x-rays , ultraviolet light , and infrared light have also brought new insights to astronomy .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: As each of these regions of the spectrum has opened , new discoveries have been made that could not have been made otherwise .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: Astronomers hope that the same holds true of gravitational waves .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: Gravitational waves have two important and unique properties .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: First , there is no need for any type of matter to be present nearby in order for the waves to be generated by a binary system of uncharged black holes , which would emit no electromagnetic radiation .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: Second , gravitational waves can pass through any intervening matter without being scattered significantly .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: Whereas light from distant stars may be blocked out by interstellar dust , for example , gravitational waves will pass through essentially unimpeded .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: These two features allow gravitational waves to carry information about astronomical phenomena never before observed by humans .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: The sources of gravitational waves described above are in the low - frequency end of the gravitational - wave spectrum ( 10−7 to 105 Hz ) .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: An astrophysical source at the high - frequency end of the gravitational - wave spectrum ( above 105 Hz and probably 1010 Hz ) generates relic gravitational waves that are theorized to be faint imprints of the Big Bang like the cosmic microwave background ( see gravitational wave background ) .

column1: Which techniques were use to originally make astronomical observations ?
column2: At these high frequencies it is potentially possible that the sources may be " man made " that is , gravitational waves generated and detected in the laboratory .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: X-ray binaries are binary star systems that are luminous in the X-ray part of the spectrum .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: These X-ray emissions are generally thought to be caused by one of the component stars being a compact object accreting matter from the other ( regular ) star .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: The presence of an ordinary star in such a system provides a unique opportunity for studying the central object and determining if it might be a black hole .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: If such a system emits signals that can be directly traced back to the compact object , it can not be a black hole .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: The absence of such a signal does , however , not exclude the possibility that the compact object is a neutron star .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: By studying the companion star it is often possible to obtain the orbital parameters of the system and obtain an estimate for the mass of the compact object .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: If this is much larger than the Tolman – Oppenheimer – Volkoff limit ( that is , the maximum mass a neutron star can have before collapsing ) then the object can not be a neutron star and is generally expected to be a black hole .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: The first strong candidate for a black hole , Cygnus X-1 , was discovered in this way by Charles Thomas Bolton , Louise Webster and Paul Murdin in 1972 .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: Some doubt , however , remained due to the uncertainties resultant from the companion star being much heavier than the candidate black hole .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: Currently , better candidates for black holes are found in a class of X-ray binaries called soft X-ray transients .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: In this class of system the companion star is relatively low mass allowing for more accurate estimates in the black hole mass .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: Moreover , these systems are only active in X-ray for several months once every 10–50 years .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: During the period of low X-ray emission ( called quiescence ) , the accretion disc is extremely faint allowing for detailed observation of the companion star during this period .

column1: How are X-ray binaries described ?
column2: One of the best such candidates is V404 Cyg.

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: Stem cells are undifferentiated biological cells that can differentiate into specialized cells and can divide ( through mitosis ) to produce more stem cells .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: They are found in multicellular organisms .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: In mammals , there are two broad types of stem cells : embryonic stem cells , which are isolated from the inner cell mass of blastocysts , and adult stem cells , which are found in various tissues .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: In adult organisms , stem cells and progenitor cells act as a repair system for the body , replenishing adult tissues .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: In a developing embryo , stem cells can differentiate into all the specialized cells — ectoderm , endoderm and mesoderm ( see induced pluripotent stem cells ) — but also maintain the normal turnover of regenerative organs , such as blood , skin , or intestinal tissues .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: There are three accessible sources of autologous adult stem cells in humans :

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: Bone marrow , which requires extraction by " harvesting " , that is , drilling into bone ( typically the femur or iliac crest ) ,

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: Adipose tissue ( lipid cells ) , which requires extraction by liposuction , and

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: Blood , which requires extraction through apheresis , wherein blood is drawn from the donor ( similar to a blood donation ) , and passed through a machine that extracts the stem cells and returns other portions of the blood to the donor .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: Stem cells can also be taken from umbilical cord blood just after birth .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: Of all stem cell types , autologous harvesting involves the least risk .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: By definition , autologous cells are obtained from one 's own body , just as one may bank his or her own blood for elective surgical procedures .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: Adult stem cells are frequently used in medical therapies , for example in bone marrow transplantation .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: Stem cells can now be artificially grown and transformed ( differentiated ) into specialized cell types with characteristics consistent with cells of various tissues such as muscles or nerves .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: Embryonic cell lines and autologous embryonic stem cells generated through therapeutic cloning have also been proposed as promising candidates for future therapies .

column1: What kind of organisms have stem cells ?
column2: Research into stem cells grew out of findings by Ernest A. McCulloch and James E. Till at the University of Toronto in the 1960s .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: Adult stem cells , also called somatic ( from Greek Σωματικóς , " of the body " ) stem cells , are stem cells which maintain and repair the tissue in which they are found .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: They can be found in children , as well as adults .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: Pluripotent adult stem cells are rare and generally small in number , but they can be found in umbilical cord blood and other tissues .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: Bone marrow is a rich source of adult stem cells , which have been used in treating several conditions including spinal cord injury , liver cirrhosis , chronic limb ischemia and endstage heart failure .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: The quantity of bone marrow stem cells declines with age and is greater in males than females during reproductive years .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: Much adult stem cell research to date has aimed to characterize their potency and self-renewal capabilities .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: In mice , pluripotent stem cells are directly generated from adult fibroblast cultures .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: However , mice do not live long with stem cell organs .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: Most adult stem cells are lineage - restricted ( multipotent ) and are generally referred to by their tissue origin ( mesenchymal stem cell , adipose - derived stem cell , endothelial stem cell , dental pulp stem cell , etc.

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: Adult stem cell treatments have been successfully used for many years to treat leukemia and related bone / blood cancers through bone marrow transplants .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: Adult stem cells are also used in veterinary medicine to treat tendon and ligament injuries in horses .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: The use of adult stem cells in research and therapy is not as controversial as the use of embryonic stem cells , because the production of adult stem cells does not require the destruction of an embryo .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: Additionally , in instances where adult stem cells are obtained from the intended recipient ( an autograft ) , the risk of rejection is essentially non-existent .

column1: What can adult stem cells be used for ?
column2: Consequently , more US government funding is being provided for adult stem cell research .

column1: What does " unsub " stand for ?
column2: Person of interest  is a term used by U.S. law enforcement when identifying someone involved in a criminal investigation who has not been arrested or formally accused of a crime .

column1: What does " unsub " stand for ?
column2: It has no legal meaning , but refers to someone in whom the police are " interested " , either because the person is cooperating with the investigation , may have information that would assist the investigation , or possesses certain characteristics that merit further attention .

column1: What does " unsub " stand for ?
column2: While terms such as " suspect " , " target " , and " material witness " have clear and sometimes formal definitions , " person of interest " remains undefined by the U.S. Department of Justice .

column1: What does " unsub " stand for ?
column2: Unsub  is a similar term which is short for " unknown subject " ( used often , for example , in the TV show " Criminal Minds " ) .

column1: What does " unsub " stand for ?
column2: Person of interest is sometimes used as a euphemism for " suspect " , and its careless use may encourage trials by media .

column1: What does " unsub " stand for ?
column2: With respect to terrorism investigations , Eric Lichtblau wrote in the " New York Times " : " Law enforcement officials say that the term simply reflects the new tactics required to fight terrorism .

column1: What does " unsub " stand for ?
column2: But some legal scholars say officials are trying to create a more benign public image , even as their power expands . "

column1: How do people who follow Strict Judaism handle meat and dairy foods in a meal ?

column1: How do people who follow Strict Judaism handle meat and dairy foods in a meal ?

column1: How do people who follow Strict Judaism handle meat and dairy foods in a meal ?

column1: How do people who follow Strict Judaism handle meat and dairy foods in a meal ?

column1: How do people who follow Strict Judaism handle meat and dairy foods in a meal ?
column2: The ethical reasons for avoiding dairy include how dairy is produced , how the animals are handled , and the environmental effect of dairy production .

column1: How did the Allies have an advantage ?
column2: In Europe , before the outbreak of the war , the Allies had significant advantages in both population and economics .

column1: How did the Allies have an advantage ?
column2: In 1938 , the Western Allies ( United Kingdom , France , Poland and British Dominions ) had a 30 percent larger population and a 30 percent higher gross domestic product than the European Axis ( Germany and Italy ) ; if colonies are included , it then gives the Allies more than a 5:1 advantage in population and nearly 2:1 advantage in GDP.

column1: How did the Allies have an advantage ?
column2: In Asia at the same time , China had roughly six times the population of Japan , but only an 89 percent higher GDP ; this is reduced to three times the population and only a 38 percent higher GDP if Japanese colonies are included .

column1: How did the Allies have an advantage ?
column2: Though the Allies ' economic and population advantages were largely mitigated during the initial rapid blitzkrieg attacks of Germany and Japan , they became the decisive factor by 1942 , after the United States and Soviet Union joined the Allies , as the war largely settled into one of attrition .

column1: How did the Allies have an advantage ?
column2: While the Allies ' ability to out-produce the Axis is often attributed to the Allies having more access to natural resources , other factors , such as Germany and Japan 's reluctance to employ women in the labour force , Allied strategic bombing , and Germany 's late shift to a war economy contributed significantly .

column1: How did the Allies have an advantage ?
column2: Additionally , neither Germany nor Japan planned to fight a protracted war , and were not equipped to do so .

column1: How did the Allies have an advantage ?
column2: To improve their production , Germany and Japan used millions of slave labourers ; Germany used about 12 million people , mostly from Eastern Europe , while Japan pressed more than 18 million people in Far East Asia .

column1: Chernobyl is affected by which cancer , being it 's main health impact ?

column1: Chernobyl is affected by which cancer , being it 's main health impact ?

column1: In which British city was the first set of modern rules for football established ?
column2: In 1848 , at Cambridge University , Mr. H. de Winton and Mr. J.C. Thring , who were both formerly at Shrewsbury School , called a meeting at Trinity College , Cambridge with 12 other representatives from Eton , Harrow , Rugby , Winchester and Shrewsbury .

column1: In which British city was the first set of modern rules for football established ?
column2: An eight - hour meeting produced what amounted to the first set of modern rules , known as the " Cambridge rules " .

column1: In which British city was the first set of modern rules for football established ?
column2: No copy of these rules now exists , but a revised version from circa 1856 is held in the library of Shrewsbury School .

column1: In which British city was the first set of modern rules for football established ?
column2: The rules clearly favour the kicking game .

column1: In which British city was the first set of modern rules for football established ?
column2: Handling was only allowed " when a player catches the ball directly from the foot " entitling them to a free kick and there was a primitive offside rule , disallowing players from " loitering " around the opponents ' goal .

column1: In which British city was the first set of modern rules for football established ?
column2: The Cambridge rules were not widely adopted outside English public schools and universities ( but it was arguably the most significant influence on the Football Association committee members responsible for formulating the rules of Association football ) .

column1: What types of methods do various authors beieve were used to move Stonehenge ?

column1: What types of methods do various authors beieve were used to move Stonehenge ?

column1: What types of methods do various authors beieve were used to move Stonehenge ?

column1: What types of methods do various authors beieve were used to move Stonehenge ?

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: Many of the initial Soviet interpreters of the Revolution were themselves Bolshevik revolutionaries .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: ( For example , the revolutionary Leon Trotsky wrote a major narrative of the October Revolution . )

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: After the initial wave of revolutionary narratives , Soviet historians worked within “ narrow guidelines ” defined by the Soviet government .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: The rigidity of interpretive possibilities reached its height under Joseph Stalin .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: Soviet historians of the October Revolution interpreted the Revolution so as to establish the legitimacy of Marxist ideology , and also the Bolshevik regime .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: To establish the accuracy of Marxist ideology , Soviet historians generally described the Revolution as the product of class struggle .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: They maintained that the Revolution was the supreme event in a world history governed by historical laws .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: The Bolshevik Party is placed at the center of the Revolution , exposing the errors of both the moderate Provisional Government and the spurious “ socialist ” Mensheviks in the Petrograd Soviet .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: Guided by Vladimir Lenin 's leadership and his firm grasp of scientific Marxist theory , the Party led the “ logically predetermined ” events of the October Revolution from beginning to end .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: The events were , according to these historians , logically predetermined because of the socio-economic development of Russia , where the monopoly industrial capitalism alienated the masses .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: In this view , the Bolshevik party took the leading role in organizing these alienated industrial workers , and thereby established the construction of the first socialist state .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: Although Soviet historiography of the October Revolution stayed relatively constant until 1991 , it did undergo some changes .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: Following Stalin ’s death , historians such as E. N. Burdzhalov and P. V. Volobuev published historical research that deviated significantly from the party line in refining the doctrine that the Bolshevik victory “ was predetermined by the state of Russia ’s socio-economic development ” .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: These historians , who comprised the “ New Directions Group ” , posited that the complex nature of the October Revolution “ could only be explained by a multi-causal analysis , not by recourse to the mono-causality of monopoly capitalism ” .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: For them , the central actor is still the Bolshevik party , but this party triumphed “ because it alone could solve the preponderance of ‘ general democratic ’ tasks the country faced ” ( such as the struggle for peace , the exploitation of landlords , and so on .

column1: Who took the leading role in organizing the alienated industrial workers ?
column2: ) During the late Soviet period , the opening of select Soviet archives during glasnost sparked innovative research that broke away from some aspects of Marxism - Leninism , though the key features of the orthodox Soviet view remained intact .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: Stereotactic radiation is a specialized type of external beam radiation therapy .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: It uses focused radiation beams targeting a well - defined tumor using extremely detailed imaging scans .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: Radiation oncologists perform stereotactic treatments , often with the help of a neurosurgeon for tumors in the brain or spine .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: There are two types of stereotactic radiation .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: Stereotactic radiosurgery ( SRS ) is when doctors use a single or several stereotactic radiation treatments of the brain or spine .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: Stereotactic body radiation therapy ( SBRT ) refers to one or several stereotactic radiation treatments with the body , such as the lungs .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: Some doctors say an advantage to stereotactic treatments are they deliver the right amount of radiation to the cancer in a shorter amount of time than traditional treatments , which can often take six to 11 weeks .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: Plus treatments are given with extreme accuracy , which should limit the effect of the radiation on healthy tissues .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: One problem with stereotactic treatments is that they are only suitable for certain small tumors .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: Stereotactic treatments can be confusing because many hospitals call the treatments by the name of the manufacturer rather than calling it SRS or SBRT.

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: Brand names for these treatments include Axesse , Cyberknife , Gamma Knife , Novalis , Primatom , Synergy , X-Knife , TomoTherapy , Trilogy and Truebeam .

column1: How much time do radiation treatments for cancer take ?
column2: This list changes as equipment manufacturers continue to develop new , specialized technologies to treat cancers .

column1: What does tracking of near - Earth objects assist in predicting ?
column2: One of the oldest fields in astronomy , and in all of science , is the measurement of the positions of celestial objects .

column1: What does tracking of near - Earth objects assist in predicting ?
column2: Historically , accurate knowledge of the positions of the Sun , Moon , planets and stars has been essential in celestial navigation ( the use of celestial objects to guide navigation ) and in the making of calendars .

column1: What does tracking of near - Earth objects assist in predicting ?
column2: Careful measurement of the positions of the planets has led to a solid understanding of gravitational perturbations , and an ability to determine past and future positions of the planets with great accuracy , a field known as celestial mechanics .

column1: What does tracking of near - Earth objects assist in predicting ?
column2: More recently the tracking of near - Earth objects will allow for predictions of close encounters , and potential collisions , with the Earth .

column1: What does tracking of near - Earth objects assist in predicting ?
column2: The measurement of stellar parallax of nearby stars provides a fundamental baseline in the cosmic distance ladder that is used to measure the scale of the universe .

column1: What does tracking of near - Earth objects assist in predicting ?
column2: Parallax measurements of nearby stars provide an absolute baseline for the properties of more distant stars , as their properties can be compared .

column1: What does tracking of near - Earth objects assist in predicting ?
column2: Measurements of radial velocity and proper motion plot the movement of these systems through the Milky Way galaxy .

column1: What does tracking of near - Earth objects assist in predicting ?
column2: Astrometric results are the basis used to calculate the distribution of dark matter in the galaxy .

column1: What does tracking of near - Earth objects assist in predicting ?
column2: During the 1990s , the measurement of the stellar wobble of nearby stars was used to detect large extrasolar planets orbiting nearby stars .

column1: Where did the word " chocolate " in English come from ?

column1: Why is gene transfer important in antibiotic resistance ?

column1: Why is gene transfer important in antibiotic resistance ?

column1: Why is gene transfer important in antibiotic resistance ?

column1: Why is gene transfer important in antibiotic resistance ?

column1: Why is gene transfer important in antibiotic resistance ?

column1: Why is gene transfer important in antibiotic resistance ?

column1: Why is gene transfer important in antibiotic resistance ?

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: Association croquet is the name of an advanced game of croquet , played at international level .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: It involves four balls teamed in pairs , with both balls going through every hoop for one pair to win .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: The game 's distinguishing feature is the " croquet " shot : when certain balls hit other balls , extra shots are allowed .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: The six hoops are arranged three at each end of the court , with a centre peg .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: In association croquet one side takes the black and blue balls , the other takes red and yellow .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: At each turn , players can choose to play with either of their balls for that turn .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: At the start of a turn , the player plays a stroke .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: If the player either hits the ball through the correct hoop ( " runs " the hoop ) , or hits another ball ( a " roquet " ) , the turn continues .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: Following a roquet , the player picks up his or her own ball and puts it down next to the ball that it hit .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: The next shot is played with the two balls touching : this is the " croquet stroke " from which the game takes its name .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: After the croquet stroke , the player plays a " continuation " stroke , during which the player may again attempt to make a roquet or run a hoop .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: Each of the other three balls may be roqueted once in a turn before a hoop is run , after which they become available to be roqueted again .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: The winner of the game is the team who completes the set circuit of six hoops ( and then back again the other way ) , with both balls , and then strikes the centre peg ( making a total of 13 points per ball = 26 ) .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: Good players may make " breaks " of several hoops in a single turn .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: The best players may take a ball round a full circuit in one turn .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: Advanced play  ( a variant of association play for expert players ) gives penalties to a player who runs certain hoops in a turn , to allow the opponent a chance of getting back into the game ; feats of skill such as triple peels or better , in which the partner ball ( or occasionally an opponent ball ) is caused to run a number of hoops in a turn by the striker 's ball help avoid these penalties .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?
column2: A handicap system ( ' bisques ' ) provides less experienced players a chance of winning against more formidable opponents .

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?

column1: what is the discerning aspect of croquet ?

column2: The world 's top 10 association croquet players as of February 2014 are Robert Fletcher ( Australia ) , Chris Clarke ( New Zealand ) , Reg Bamford ( South Africa ) , Paddy Chapman ( New Zealand ) , Aaron Westerby ( New Zealand ) , Greg Bryant ( New Zealand ) , Toby Garrison ( New Zealand ) , Robert Fulford ( England ) , David Maugham ( England ) , and Jamie Burch ( England ) .

column1: What does following of close Earth objects help with anticipating ?

column1: What does following of close Earth objects help with anticipating ?

column1: What does following of close Earth objects help with anticipating ?
column2: Careful measurement of the positions of the planets has led to a solid understanding of gravitational perturbations , and an ability to determine past and future positions of the planets with great accuracy , a field known as celestial mechanics .

column1: What does following of close Earth objects help with anticipating ?
column2: More recently the tracking of near - Earth objects will allow for predictions of close encounters , and potential collisions , with the Earth .

column1: What does following of close Earth objects help with anticipating ?
column2: The measurement of stellar parallax of nearby stars provides a fundamental baseline in the cosmic distance ladder that is used to measure the scale of the universe .

column1: What does following of close Earth objects help with anticipating ?
column2: Parallax measurements of nearby stars provide an absolute baseline for the properties of more distant stars , as their properties can be compared .

column1: What does following of close Earth objects help with anticipating ?
column2: Measurements of radial velocity and proper motion plot the movement of these systems through the Milky Way galaxy .

column1: What does following of close Earth objects help with anticipating ?
column2: Astrometric results are the basis used to calculate the distribution of dark matter in the galaxy .

column1: What does following of close Earth objects help with anticipating ?
column2: During the 1990s , the measurement of the stellar wobble of nearby stars was used to detect large extrasolar planets orbiting nearby stars .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: The provisions were intended to make the incapable of offensive action and to encourage international disarmament .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: Germany was to demobilize sufficient soldiers by 31 March 1920 , to leave an army of no more than in a maximum of seven infantry and three cavalry divisions .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: The treaty laid down the organisation of the divisions and support units , and the General Staff was to be dissolved .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: Military schools for officer training were limited to three , one school per arm and conscription was to abolished .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: Private soldiers and Non-commissioned officers were to be retained for at least twelve years and officers for a minimum of with former officers being forbidden to attend military exercises .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: To prevent Germany from building up a large cadre of trained men , the number of men allowed to leave early was limited .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: The number of civilian staff supporting the army was reduced and the police force reduced to its pre-war size , with increases limited to population increases ; paramilitary forces were forbidden .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: The Rhineland was to be demilitarized , all fortifications in the Rhineland and east of the river were to be demolished and new construction was forbidden .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: Military structures and fortifications on the islands of Heligoland and Düne were to be destroyed .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: Germany was prohibited from the arms trade , limits were imposed on the type and quantity of weapons and prohibited from the manufacture or stockpile of chemical weapons , armored cars , tanks and military aircraft .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: The German navy was allowed six pre-dreadnought battleships and was limited to a maximum of six light cruisers ( not exceeding ) , twelve destroyers ( not exceeding ) and twelve torpedo boats ( not exceeding ) and was forbidden submarines .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: The manpower of the navy was not to exceed including manning for the fleet , coast defences , signal stations , administration , other land services , officers and men of all grades and corps.

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?
column2: The number of officers and warrant officers was not allowed to exceed Germany surrendered eight battleships , eight light cruisers , forty - two destroyers , and fifty torpedo boats for decommissioning .

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?

column1: How long does Germany took to make a reentry in aircraft industry ?

column1: When giving live vaccines , who is most endangered by them ?

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: Mutations are changes in the DNA sequence of a cell 's genome .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: When mutations occur , they can either have no effect , alter the product of a gene , or prevent the gene from functioning .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: Based on studies in the fly " Drosophila melanogaster " , it has been suggested that if a mutation changes a protein produced by a gene , this will probably be harmful , with about 70 % of these mutations having damaging effects , and the remainder being either neutral or weakly beneficial .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: Mutations can involve large sections of a chromosome becoming duplicated ( usually by genetic recombination ) , which can introduce extra copies of a gene into a genome .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: Extra copies of genes are a major source of the raw material needed for new genes to evolve .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: This is important because most new genes evolve within gene families from pre-existing genes that share common ancestors .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: For example , the human eye uses four genes to make structures that sense light : three for colour vision and one for night vision ; all four are descended from a single ancestral gene .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: New genes can be generated from an ancestral gene when a duplicate copy mutates and acquires a new function .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: This process is easier once a gene has been duplicated because it increases the redundancy of the system ; one gene in the pair can acquire a new function while the other copy continues to perform its original function .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: Other types of mutations can even generate entirely new genes from previously noncoding DNA .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: The generation of new genes can also involve small parts of several genes being duplicated , with these fragments then recombining to form new combinations with new functions .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: When new genes are assembled from shuffling pre-existing parts , domains act as modules with simple independent functions , which can be mixed together to produce new combinations with new and complex functions .

column1: What are large enzymes that make antibiotics called ?
column2: For example , polyketide synthases are large enzymes that make antibiotics ; they contain up to one hundred independent domains that each catalyse one step in the overall process , like a step in an assembly line .
