column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Different cancers respond differently to radiation therapy .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: The response of a cancer to radiation is described by its radiosensitivity .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Highly radiosensitive cancer cells are rapidly killed by modest doses of radiation .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: These include leukemias , most lymphomas and germ cell tumors .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: The majority of epithelial cancers are only moderately radiosensitive , and require a significantly higher dose of radiation ( 60-70 Gy ) to achieve a radical cure .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Some types of cancer are notably radioresistant , that is , much higher doses are required to produce a radical cure than may be safe in clinical practice .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Renal cell cancer and melanoma are generally considered to be radioresistant .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: It is important to distinguish the radiosensitivity of a particular tumor , which to some extent is a laboratory measure , from the radiation " curability " of a cancer in actual clinical practice .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: For example , leukemias are not generally curable with radiation therapy , because they are disseminated through the body .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Lymphoma may be radically curable if it is localised to one area of the body .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Similarly , many of the common , moderately radioresponsive tumors are routinely treated with curative doses of radiation therapy if they are at an early stage .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: For example : non-melanoma skin cancer , head and neck cancer , breast cancer , non-small cell lung cancer , cervical cancer , anal cancer , prostate cancer .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Metastatic cancers are generally incurable with radiation therapy because it is not possible to treat the whole body .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Before treatment , a CT scan is often performed to identify the tumor and surrounding normal structures .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: The patient is then sent for a simulation so that molds can be created to be used during treatment .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: The patient receives small skin marks to guide the placement of treatment fields .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: The response of a tumor to radiation therapy is also related to its size .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: For complex reasons , very large tumors respond less well to radiation than smaller tumors or microscopic disease .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Various strategies are used to overcome this effect .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: The most common technique is surgical resection prior to radiation therapy .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: This is most commonly seen in the treatment of breast cancer with wide local excision or mastectomy followed by adjuvant radiation therapy .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Another method is to shrink the tumor with neoadjuvant chemotherapy prior to radical radiation therapy .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: A third technique is to enhance the radiosensitivity of the cancer by giving certain drugs during a course of radiation therapy .

column1: Does chemo affect all cancers the same ?
column2: Examples of radiosensiting drugs include : Cisplatin , Nimorazole , and Cetuximab .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: The Last Supper has been a popular subject in Christian art .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: Depictions of the Last Supper in Christian art date back to early Christianity and can be seen in the Catacombs of Rome .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: Byzantine artists frequently focused on the Apostles receiving Communion , rather than the reclining figures having a meal .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: By the Renaissance , the Last Supper was a favorite topic in Italian art .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: There are three major themes in the depictions of the last supper .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: The first theme is the dramatic and dynamic depiction of Jesus ' announcement of his betrayal .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: The second theme is the moment of the institution of the tradition of the Eucharist .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: The depictions here are generally solemn and mystical .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: The third major theme is the farewell of Jesus to his disciples , in which Judas Iscariot is no longer present , having left the supper .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: The depictions here are generally melancholy , as Jesus prepares his disciples for his departure .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: There are also other , less frequently depicted scenes , such as the washing of the feet of the disciples .

column1: What are the prominent themes depicted in the last supper ?
column2: Well known examples include Leonardo da Vinci 's depiction , which is considered the first work of High Renaissance art due to its high level of harmony , Tintoretto 's depiction which is unusual in that it includes secondary characters carrying or taking the dishes from the table and Salvadore Dali 's depiction combines the typical Christian themes with modern approaches of Surrealism .

column1: What were the consequences of Cao 's tactical mistake ?

column1: What were the consequences of Cao 's tactical mistake ?

column1: When was the first reference of coffee in the English language

column1: When was the first reference of coffee in the English language

column1: When was the first reference of coffee in the English language

column1: In San Francisco , where do homeless people gather ?
column2: The City of San Francisco has sometimes grappled with what to do about camps of homeless people living in Golden Gate Park , which have been criticized as unsanitary , and " demoralizing " for park users and workers .

column1: In San Francisco , where do homeless people gather ?
column2: The camps have been described by journalists as full of garbage , broken glass , hypodermic needles , and human excrement , and the people in them are described as suffering from serious addictions and often behaving aggressively with police and park gardeners .

column1: In San Francisco , where do homeless people gather ?
column2: There have been occasional incidents of violence against homeless people in the park , including the 2010 park beating to death of a homeless man and an attack on park visitors by dogs owned by a park resident , also in 2010 .

column1: In San Francisco , where do homeless people gather ?
column2: In the 1990s , then - Mayor Willie Brown sought unsuccessfully to borrow the Oakland Police Department 's helicopters in order to find homeless people 's camps .

column1: In San Francisco , where do homeless people gather ?
column2: Starting in 1988 under then - mayor Art Agnos , and continuing under the direction of subsequent mayors including Frank Jordan , Willie Brown , and Gavin Newsom , San Francisco police have conducted intermittent sweeps of the park aimed at eliminating the camps .

column1: In San Francisco , where do homeless people gather ?
column2: Tactics have included information campaigns designed to inform homeless residents about city services available to help them ; waking sleeping homeless people and making them leave the park ; issuing citations for infractions and misdemeanors such as camping , trespassing , or public intoxication , which carry penalties of $ 75 to $ 100 ; and the seizure and removal from the park of homeless people 's possessions .

column1: In San Francisco , where do homeless people gather ?
column2: The crackdowns have been criticized by anti-poverty activists and civil liberties groups , who say they attack only the symptoms of homelessness while ignoring its root causes , and criminalize the poor for their poverty while ignoring their property rights and constitutional rights .

column1: In San Francisco , where do homeless people gather ?
column2: In 2006 , the American Civil Liberties Union brought a lawsuit against the city government on behalf of 10 homeless people , alleging property violations by the city during sweeps in Golden Gate Park the year before .

column1: Why do electromagnetism formulas need to be adjusted in the cgs system ?

column1: Why do electromagnetism formulas need to be adjusted in the cgs system ?

column1: Why do electromagnetism formulas need to be adjusted in the cgs system ?

column1: Why do electromagnetism formulas need to be adjusted in the cgs system ?
column2: This is because there is no one - to - one correspondence between electromagnetic units in SI and those in CGS , as is the case for mechanical units .

column1: Why do electromagnetism formulas need to be adjusted in the cgs system ?
column2: Furthermore , within CGS , there are several plausible choices of electromagnetic units , leading to different unit " sub - systems " , including Gaussian , " ESU " , " EMU " , and Heaviside – Lorentz .

column1: Why do electromagnetism formulas need to be adjusted in the cgs system ?
column2: Among these choices , Gaussian units are the most common today , and in fact the phrase " CGS units " is often used to refer specifically to CGS - Gaussian units .

column2: In addition to being a major source of variation , mutation may also function as a mechanism of evolution when there are different probabilities at the molecular level for different mutations to occur , a process known as mutation bias .

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?
column2: If two genotypes , for example one with the nucleotide G and another with the nucleotide A in the same position , have the same fitness , but mutation from G to A happens more often than mutation from A to G , then genotypes with A will tend to evolve .

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?
column2: If selection would favor either one out of two mutations , but there is no extra advantage to having both , then the mutation that occurs the most frequently is the one that is most likely to become fixed in a population .

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?

column1: What happens what selection is weak ?

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: The Kipferl , ancestor of the croissant , has been documented in Austria going back at least as far as the 13th century , in various shapes .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: The Kipferl can be made plain or with nut or other fillings ( some consider the rugelach a form of Kipferl ) .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: The " birth " of the croissant itself – that is , its adaptation from the plainer form of Kipferl , before the invention of Viennoiserie – can be dated with some precision to at latest 1839 ( some say 1838 ) , when an Austrian artillery officer , August Zang , founded a Viennese bakery ( " Boulangerie Viennoise " ) at 92 , rue de Richelieu in Paris .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: This bakery , which served Viennese specialities including the Kipferl and the Vienna loaf , quickly became popular and inspired French imitators ( and the concept , if not the term , viennoiserie , a 20th - century term for supposedly Vienna - style pastries ) .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: The French version of the Kipferl was named for its crescent ( " croissant " ) shape and has become a identifiable shape across the world .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: Alan Davidson , editor of the " Oxford Companion to Food " , found no printed recipe for the present - day croissant in any French recipe book before the early 20th century ; the earliest French reference to a croissant he found was among the " fantasy or luxury breads " in Payen 's " Des substances alimentaires " , 1853 .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: However , early recipes for non-laminated croissants can be found in the nineteenth century and at least one reference to croissants as an established French bread appeared as early as 1850 .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: Zang himself returned to Austria in 1848 to become a press magnate , but the bakery remained popular for some time after , and was mentioned in several works of the time : " This same M. Zank ... founded around 1830 , in Paris , the famous Boulangerie viennoise " .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: Several sources praise this bakery 's products : " Paris is of exquisite delicacy ; and , in particular , the succulent products of the Boulangerie Viennoise " ; " which seemed to us as fine as if it came from the Viennese bakery on the rue de Richelieu " .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: By 1869 , the croissant was well established enough to be mentioned as a breakfast staple , and in 1872 , Charles Dickens wrote ( in his periodical " All the Year Round " ) of : the workman 's pain de ménage and the soldier 's pain de munition , to the dainty croissant on the boudoir tableThe puff pastry technique which now characterizes the croissant was already mentioned in the late 17th century , when La Varenne 's " Le Cuisinier françois " gave a recipe for it in the 1680 – and possibly earlier – editions .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: It was typically used , not on its own , but for shells holding other ingredients ( as in a vol - au - vent ) .

column1: what is the origin of the croissant 's name ?
column2: But it does not appear to be mentioned in relation to the croissant until the twentieth century .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: Mutations are changes in the DNA sequence of a cell 's genome .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: When mutations occur , they can either have no effect , alter the product of a gene , or prevent the gene from functioning .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: Based on studies in the fly " Drosophila melanogaster " , it has been suggested that if a mutation changes a protein produced by a gene , this will probably be harmful , with about 70 % of these mutations having damaging effects , and the remainder being either neutral or weakly beneficial .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: Mutations can involve large sections of a chromosome becoming duplicated ( usually by genetic recombination ) , which can introduce extra copies of a gene into a genome .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: Extra copies of genes are a major source of the raw material needed for new genes to evolve .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: This is important because most new genes evolve within gene families from pre-existing genes that share common ancestors .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: For example , the human eye uses four genes to make structures that sense light : three for colour vision and one for night vision ; all four are descended from a single ancestral gene .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: New genes can be generated from an ancestral gene when a duplicate copy mutates and acquires a new function .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: This process is easier once a gene has been duplicated because it increases the redundancy of the system ; one gene in the pair can acquire a new function while the other copy continues to perform its original function .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: Other types of mutations can even generate entirely new genes from previously noncoding DNA .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: The generation of new genes can also involve small parts of several genes being duplicated , with these fragments then recombining to form new combinations with new functions .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: When new genes are assembled from shuffling pre-existing parts , domains act as modules with simple independent functions , which can be mixed together to produce new combinations with new and complex functions .

column1: Antibiotics for large enzymes are called what ?
column2: For example , polyketide synthases are large enzymes that make antibiotics ; they contain up to one hundred independent domains that each catalyse one step in the overall process , like a step in an assembly line .

column1: What is the purpose of hematophathology ?

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: Epigenetics is the study of mitotically and / or meiotically heritable changes in gene function that can not be explained by changes in the underlying DNA sequence but cause the organism 's genes to behave ( or " express themselves " ) differently .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: One example of epigenetic change is the marking of the genes by DNA methylation which determines whether they will be expressed or not .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: Gene expression can also be controlled by repressor proteins that attach to silencer regions of the DNA and prevent that region of the DNA code from being expressed .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: Epigenetic marks may be added or removed from the DNA during programmed stages of development of the plant , and are responsible , for example , for the differences between anthers , petals and normal leaves , despite the fact that they all have the same underlying genetic code .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: Epigenetic changes may be temporary or may remain through successive cell divisions for the remainder of the cell 's life .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: Some epigenetic changes have been shown to be heritable , while others are reset in the germ cells .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: Epigenetic changes in eukaryotic biology serve to regulate the process of cellular differentiation .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: During morphogenesis , totipotent stem cells become the various pluripotent cell lines of the embryo , which in turn become fully differentiated cells .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: A single fertilized egg cell , the zygote , gives rise to the many different plant cell types including parenchyma , xylem vessel elements , phloem sieve tubes , guard cells of the epidermis , etc.

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: as it continues to divide .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: The process results from the epigenetic activation of some genes and inhibition of others .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: Unlike animals , many plant cells , particularly those of the parenchyma , do not terminally differentiate , remaining totipotent with the ability to give rise to a new individual plant .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: Exceptions include highly lignified cells , the sclerenchyma and xylem which are dead at maturity , and the phloem sieve tubes which lack nuclei .

column1: What is Epigenetics ?
column2: While plants use many of the same epigenetic mechanisms as animals , such as chromatin remodeling , an alternative hypothesis is that plants set their gene expression patterns using positional information from the environment and surrounding cells to determine their developmental fate .

column1: What shape does a snorkel for a swimmer usually come in ?

column1: What shape does a snorkel for a swimmer usually come in ?

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: The defining feature of a black hole is the appearance of an event horizon — a boundary in spacetime through which matter and light can only pass inward towards the mass of the black hole .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: Nothing , not even light , can escape from inside the event horizon .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: The event horizon is referred to as such because if an event occurs within the boundary , information from that event can not reach an outside observer , making it impossible to determine if such an event occurred .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: As predicted by general relativity , the presence of a mass deforms spacetime in such a way that the paths taken by particles bend towards the mass .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: At the event horizon of a black hole , this deformation becomes so strong that there are no paths that lead away from the black hole .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: To a distant observer , clocks near a black hole appear to tick more slowly than those further away from the black hole .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: Due to this effect , known as gravitational time dilation , an object falling into a black hole appears to slow down as it approaches the event horizon , taking an infinite time to reach it .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: At the same time , all processes on this object slow down , for a fixed outside observer , causing emitted light to appear redder and dimmer , an effect known as gravitational redshift .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: Eventually , at a point just before it reaches the event horizon , the falling object becomes so dim that it can no longer be seen .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: On the other hand , an indestructible observer falling into a black hole does not notice any of these effects as he crosses the event horizon .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: According to his own clock , which appears to him to tick normally , he crosses the event horizon after a finite time without noting any singular behaviour .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: In particular , he is unable to determine exactly when he crosses it , as it is impossible to determine the location of the event horizon from local observations .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: The shape of the event horizon of a black hole is always approximately spherical .

column1: What can escape from the inside of an event horizon of a black hole ?
column2: For non-rotating ( static ) black holes the geometry is precisely spherical , while for rotating black holes the sphere is somewhat oblate .

column1: What does gravity influence , assuming the equivalence principle holds ?

column1: What does gravity influence , assuming the equivalence principle holds ?

column1: What does gravity influence , assuming the equivalence principle holds ?

column1: What does gravity influence , assuming the equivalence principle holds ?
column2: However , at the current level of accuracy , these observations can not distinguish between general relativity and other theories in which the equivalence principle is valid .

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: Perhaps no other painting in Western Art has enjoyed such a varying array of intriguing interpretations .

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: Academic theories tend towards two schools : " the literal " and " the literary . "

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: The " literal " includes both " he painted what he saw " and the " hallucinatory genius " arguments ( as an individual 's hallucinations are indistinguishable from real life ) while the " literary " suggest that inspiration blossomed from some written source ; most often cited for van Gogh 's " Starry Night " are The Bible , Walt Whitman and Victor Hugo .

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: Legendary 20th century art historian Albert Boime is generally credited with the best " literal " theory by proving , in conjunction with three Astronomer colleagues at UCLA the position of the stars from van Gogh 's window in the asylum at Saint - Rémy - de - Provence at 4 a.m. on June 19 , 1889 , the day van Gogh wrote his brother that he had completed the painting .

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: In a 1985 lecture to the American Astronomical Society , Boime compared the positions of the moon and Venus that night and showed that they corresponded to the positions of the celestial objects in the painting .

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: While Boime and his lead astronomer , Charles Whitney agreed the large star above the horizon is the Morning Star , they failed to agree on the arrangement of the other stars .

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: Boime claimed they constituted the constellation of Aries , while Whitney argued it was Cygnus .

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: Boime further attempted to make the argument that van Gogh had likely seen an image of a spiral galaxy from Camille Flammarion 's " Astronomie populaire " , in an attempt to explain the existence of van Gogh 's celestial spiral jetty .

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: In his 800 - plus existing letters , however , van Gogh makes no mention of ever reading Flammarion .

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: As to the leading " literary " theories : those about The Bible range from van Gogh painting a passage out of Genesis 37 describing a dream of Joseph to an apocalyptic depiction out of the twelfth book of Revelation to a " sublimated Christ in the Garden of Gethsemane " ; while those from Whitman attempt to correlate the painting 's poetic vision within Song of Myself ; and ( what has been mistakenly attributed to Hugo 's Les Miserables ) as an inspired depiction of God as " a lighthouse in eclipse .

column1: Which literary source may have inspired Van Gogh ?
column2: This bevy of interpretations has helped keep van Gogh 's  Starry Night " firmly within the discussions and lively debates of both public and academic art history .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: If bacteria form a parasitic association with other organisms , they are classed as pathogens .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Pathogenic bacteria are a major cause of human death and disease and cause infections such as tetanus , typhoid fever , diphtheria , syphilis , cholera , foodborne illness , leprosy and tuberculosis .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: A pathogenic cause for a known medical disease may only be discovered many years after , as was the case with " Helicobacter pylori " and peptic ulcer disease .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Bacterial diseases are also important in agriculture , with bacteria causing leaf spot , fire blight and wilts in plants , as well as Johne 's disease , mastitis , salmonella and anthrax in farm animals .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Each species of pathogen has a characteristic spectrum of interactions with its human hosts .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Some organisms , such as " Staphylococcus " or " Streptococcus " , can cause skin infections , pneumonia , meningitis and even overwhelming sepsis , a systemic inflammatory response producing shock , massive vasodilation and death .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Yet these organisms are also part of the normal human flora and usually exist on the skin or in the nose without causing any disease at all .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Other organisms invariably cause disease in humans , such as the Rickettsia , which are obligate intracellular parasites able to grow and reproduce only within the cells of other organisms .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: One species of Rickettsia causes typhus , while another causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Chlamydia  , another phylum of obligate intracellular parasites , contains species that can cause pneumonia , or urinary tract infection and may be involved in coronary heart disease .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Finally , some species such as " Pseudomonas aeruginosa " , " Burkholderia cenocepacia " , and " Mycobacterium avium " are opportunistic pathogens and cause disease mainly in people suffering from immunosuppression or cystic fibrosis .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Bacterial infections may be treated with antibiotics , which are classified as bacteriocidal if they kill bacteria , or bacteriostatic if they just prevent bacterial growth .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: There are many types of antibiotics and each class inhibits a process that is different in the pathogen from that found in the host .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: An example of how antibiotics produce selective toxicity are chloramphenicol and puromycin , which inhibit the bacterial ribosome , but not the structurally different eukaryotic ribosome .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Antibiotics are used both in treating human disease and in intensive farming to promote animal growth , where they may be contributing to the rapid development of antibiotic resistance in bacterial populations .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Infections can be prevented by antiseptic measures such as sterilizing the skin prior to piercing it with the needle of a syringe , and by proper care of indwelling catheters .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Surgical and dental instruments are also sterilized to prevent contamination by bacteria .

column1: What do organisms cause in humans ?
column2: Disinfectants such as bleach are used to kill bacteria or other pathogens on surfaces to prevent contamination and further reduce the risk of infection .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: As a result , the ISS is equipped with internal and external communication systems used for different purposes .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: The Russian Orbital Segment communicates directly with the ground via the " Lira " antenna mounted to " Zvezda " .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: The " Lira " antenna also has the capability to use the " Luch " data relay satellite system .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: This system , used for communications with " Mir " , fell into disrepair during the 1990s , and as a result is no longer in use , although two new " Luch " satellites — " Luch " -5A and " Luch " -5B — were launched in 2011 and 2012 respectively to restore the operational capability of the system .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: Another Russian communications system is the Voskhod - M , which enables internal telephone communications between " Zvezda " , " Zarya " , " Pirs " , " Poisk " and the USOS , and also provides a VHF radio link to ground control centres via antennas on " Zvezda " exterior .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: The US Orbital Segment ( USOS ) makes use of two separate radio links mounted in the Z1 truss structure : the S band ( used for audio ) and Ku band ( used for audio , video and data ) systems .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: These transmissions are routed via the United States Tracking and Data Relay Satellite System ( TDRSS ) in geostationary orbit , which allows for almost continuous real - time communications with NASA 's Mission Control Center ( MCC - H ) in Houston .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: Data channels for the Canadarm2 , European " Columbus " laboratory and Japanese " Kibō " modules are routed via the S band and Ku band systems , although the European Data Relay Satellite System and a similar Japanese system will eventually complement the TDRSS in this role .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: Communications between modules are carried on an internal digital wireless network.UHF radio is used by astronauts and cosmonauts conducting EVAs .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: UHF is employed by other spacecraft that dock to or undock from the station , such as Soyuz , Progress , HTV , ATV and the Space Shuttle ( except the shuttle also makes use of the S band and Ku band systems via TDRSS ) , to receive commands from Mission Control and ISS crewmembers .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: Automated spacecraft are fitted with their own communications equipment ; the ATV uses a laser attached to the spacecraft and equipment attached to " Zvezda " , known as the Proximity Communications Equipment , to accurately dock to the station .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?
column2: Heat generated by the laptops does not rise , but stagnates surrounding the laptop , so additional forced ventilation is required .

column1: Why was the migration from Microsoft Windows made ?

column1: Is MRI bad ?

column1: Is MRI bad ?

column1: Is MRI bad ?

column1: Is MRI bad ?
column2: An Australian study found that one in every 1800 CT scans was associated with an excess cancer .

column1: Is MRI bad ?

column1: Is MRI bad ?
column2: However , although the cost of MRI has fallen , making it more competitive with CT , there are not many common imaging scenarios in which MRI can simply replace CT , although this substitution has been suggested for the imaging of liver disease .

column1: Is MRI bad ?
column2: The effect of low doses of radiation on carcinogenesis are also disputed .

column1: Is MRI bad ?

column1: Is MRI bad ?
column2: In a comparison of possible genotoxic effects of MRI compared with those of CT scans , Knuuti et al.

column1: Is MRI bad ?
column2: noted that although previous studies have demonstrated DNA damage associated with MRI , " the long - term biological and clinical significance of DNA double - strand breaks induced by MRI remains unknown " .

column1: Is MRI bad ?

column1: Is MRI bad ?
column2: Commonly used MRI contrast agents have a good safety profile but linear non-ionic agents in particular have been implicated in nephrogenic systemic fibrosis in patients with severely impaired renal function.MRI is contraindicated in the presence of MR - unsafe implants , and although these patients may be imaged with CT , beam hardening artefact from metallic devices , such as pacemakers and implantable cardioverter - defibrillators , may also affect image quality .

column1: Is MRI bad ?
column2: MRI is a longer investigation than CT and an exam may take between 20 - 40 mins depending on complexity .

column1: Why were farmers forced to sell their produce on consignment through wholesalers at The Lots ?

column1: Why were farmers forced to sell their produce on consignment through wholesalers at The Lots ?
column2: The farmers typically received a percentage of the final sale price for their goods .

column1: Why were farmers forced to sell their produce on consignment through wholesalers at The Lots ?

column1: Why were farmers forced to sell their produce on consignment through wholesalers at The Lots ?
column2: During the existence of the wholesale houses , which far predated the Market , there were regular rumors as well as instances of corruption in denying payment to farmers .

column1: What is the reason economists gave for the great depression during 1920s ?

column1: What is the reason economists gave for the great depression during 1920s ?

column1: What is the reason economists gave for the great depression during 1920s ?

column1: What is the reason economists gave for the great depression during 1920s ?

column1: Is a dry or wet pass more difficult ?

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?
column2: The arena itself was 83 meters by 48 meters ( 272 ft by 157 ft / 280 by 163 Roman feet ) .

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?
column2: It was restructured on numerous occasions ; at least twelve different phases of construction can be seen .

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?
column2: The " hypogeum " was connected by underground tunnels to a number of points outside the Colosseum .

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?
column2: Animals and performers were brought through the tunnel from nearby stables , with the gladiators ' barracks at the Ludus Magnus to the east also being connected by tunnels .

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?
column2: Separate tunnels were provided for the Emperor and the Vestal Virgins to permit them to enter and exit the Colosseum without needing to pass through the crowds .

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?
column2: Substantial quantities of machinery also existed in the " hypogeum " .

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?

column1: How were animals and scenery able to enter the colosseum ?

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?
column2: In addition Midway paved the way for the landings on Guadalcanal , and the prolonged attrition of the Solomon Islands campaign , both of which finally allowed the Allies to take the strategic initiative and swing onto the offensive for the rest of the Pacific War .

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?
column2: A few months after Midway , the JNAF sustained similar casualty rates at both the Battle of the Eastern Solomons and Battle of Santa Cruz , and it was these battles , combined with the constant attrition of veterans during the Solomons campaign , which were the catalyst for the sharp downward spiral in operational capability .

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?

column1: When did the Essex class fleet carriers become available ?

column1: Project Gemini was introduced in what year ?

"

column1: Project Gemini was introduced in what year ?

column1: Project Gemini was introduced in what year ?

column1: Project Gemini was introduced in what year ?
column2: Gemini 11 ( September 1966 ) , commanded by Conrad , achieved the first direct - ascent rendezvous with its Agena target on the first orbit , and used the Agena 's rocket to achieve an apogee of .

column1: Project Gemini was introduced in what year ?
column2: On Gemini 12 ( November 1966 ) , Edwin E. " Buzz " Aldrin spent over five hours working comfortably during three ( EVA ) sessions , finally proving that humans could perform productive tasks outside their spacecraft .

column2: During early tests of the Chain Home system , the slow flow of information from the CH radars and observers to the aircraft often caused them to miss their " bandits " .

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?
column2: The solution , today known as the " Dowding system " , was to create a set of reporting chains to move information from the various observation points to the pilots in their fighters .

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?
column2: It was named after its chief architect , " Stuffy " Dowding .

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?
column2: Reports from CH radars and the Royal Observer Corps were sent directly to Fighter Command Headquarters ( FCHQ ) where they were " filtered " to combine multiple reports of the same formations into single tracks .

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?

column1: What is the name of the person that forwarded information of interest to Group Headquarters ?

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .
column2: They are divided into two groups : small molecule and antibodies .

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .
column2: This allows a high dose to cancer tissues with a relatively low dose to other tissues .

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .

column1: What are the new class of cancer drugs called , which avoid the side effects of cytotoxics .

column1: When was the first recorded use of a telescope ?

column1: When was the first recorded use of a telescope ?

column1: When was the first recorded use of a telescope ?

column1: When was the first recorded use of a telescope ?

column1: When was the first recorded use of a telescope ?

column1: When was the first recorded use of a telescope ?

column1: When was the first recorded use of a telescope ?

column1: When was the first recorded use of a telescope ?

column1: When was the first recorded use of a telescope ?

column1: How are the regions of the periodic table referenced ?
column2: The different regions of the periodic table are sometimes referred to as " blocks " in recognition of the sequence in which the electron shells of the elements are filled .

column1: How are the regions of the periodic table referenced ?
column2: Each block is named according to the subshell in which the " last " electron notionally resides .

column1: How are the regions of the periodic table referenced ?
column2: The s - block comprises the first two groups ( alkali metals and alkaline earth metals ) as well as hydrogen and helium .

column1: How are the regions of the periodic table referenced ?
column2: The p - block comprises the last six groups which are groups 13 to 18 in IUPAC ( 3A to 8A in American ) and contains , among other elements , all of the metalloids .

column1: How are the regions of the periodic table referenced ?
column2: The d - block comprises groups 3 to 12 in IUPAC ( or 3B to 2B in American group numbering ) and contains all of the transition metals .

column1: How are the regions of the periodic table referenced ?
column2: The f - block , usually offset below the rest of the periodic table , comprises the lanthanides and actinides .

column1: What is the function of genetic recombination ?

column1: What is considered a good paddy - to - rice conversion ?

column1: What is considered a good paddy - to - rice conversion ?

column1: What is considered a good paddy - to - rice conversion ?

column1: What is considered a good paddy - to - rice conversion ?

column1: What is considered a good paddy - to - rice conversion ?

column1: What is considered a good paddy - to - rice conversion ?

column1: Why are rebreathers useful for such things as underwater photography and covert work ?
column2: Less common are closed circuit ( CCR ) and semi-closed ( SCR ) rebreathers , which unlike open - circuit sets that vent off all exhaled gases , process all or part of each exhaled breath for re-use by removing the carbon dioxide and replacing the oxygen used by the diver .

column1: Why are rebreathers useful for such things as underwater photography and covert work ?
column2: Rebreathers release little or no gas bubbles into the water , and use much less stored gas volume , for an equivalent depth and time because exhaled oxygen is recovered ; this has advantages for research , military , photography , and other applications .

column1: Why are rebreathers useful for such things as underwater photography and covert work ?
column2: Rebreathers are more complex and more expensive than open - circuit scuba , and special training and correct maintenance are required for them to be safely used , due to the larger variety of potential failure modes .

column1: Why are rebreathers useful for such things as underwater photography and covert work ?
column2: In a closed - circuit rebreather the oxygen partial pressure in the rebreather is controlled , so it can be maintained at a safe continuous maximum , which reduces the inert gas ( nitrogen and / or helium ) partial pressure in the breathing loop .

column1: Why are rebreathers useful for such things as underwater photography and covert work ?
column2: Minimising the inert gas loading of the diver 's tissues for a given dive profile reduces the decompression obligation .

column1: Why are rebreathers useful for such things as underwater photography and covert work ?
column2: This requires continuous monitoring of actual partial pressures with time and for maximum effectiveness requires real - time computer processing by the diver 's decompression computer .

column1: Why are rebreathers useful for such things as underwater photography and covert work ?
column2: Decompression can be much reduced compared to fixed ratio gas mixes used in other scuba systems and , as a result , divers can stay down longer or require less time to decompress .

column1: Why are rebreathers useful for such things as underwater photography and covert work ?
column2: A semi-closed circuit rebreather injects a constant mass flow of a fixed breathing gas mixture into the breathing loop , or replaces a specific percentage of the respired volume , so the partial pressure of oxygen at any time during the dive depends on the diver 's oxygen consumption and / or breathing rate .

column1: Why are rebreathers useful for such things as underwater photography and covert work ?
column2: Planning decompression requirements requires a more conservative approach for a SCR than for a CCR , but decompression computers with a real time oxygen partial pressure input can optimise decompression for these systems .

column1: Why are rebreathers useful for such things as underwater photography and covert work ?
column2: Because rebreathers produce very few bubbles , they do not disturb marine life or make a diver ’s presence known at the surface ; this is useful for underwater photography , and for covert work .

column1: What is the branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe ?
column2: Astrophysics ( from Greek " astron " , ἄστρον " star " , and " physis " , φύσις " nature " ) is the branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe , especially with " the nature of the heavenly bodies , rather than their positions or motions in space . "

column1: What is the branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe ?
column2: Among the objects studied are galaxies , stars , planets , extrasolar planets , the interstellar medium and the cosmic microwave background .

column1: What is the branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe ?
column2: Their emissions are examined across all parts of the electromagnetic spectrum , and the properties examined include luminosity , density , temperature , and chemical composition .

column1: What is the branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe ?
column2: Because astrophysics is a very broad subject , " astrophysicists " typically apply many disciplines of physics , including mechanics , electromagnetism , statistical mechanics , thermodynamics , quantum mechanics , relativity , nuclear and particle physics , and atomic and molecular physics .

column1: What is the branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe ?
column2: In practice , modern astronomical research often involves a substantial amount of work in the realm (s) of theoretical and / or observational physics .

column1: What is the branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe ?
column2: Highly elusive areas of study for astrophysicists , which are of immense interest to the public , include their attempts to determine : the properties of dark matter , dark energy , and black holes ; whether or not time travel is possible , wormholes can form , or the multiverse exists ; and the origin and ultimate fate of the universe .

column1: What is the branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe ?
column2: Topics also studied by theoretical astrophysicists include : solar system formation and evolution ; stellar dynamics and evolution ; galaxy formation and evolution ; magnetohydrodynamics ; large - scale structure of matter in the universe ; origin of cosmic rays ; general relativity and physical cosmology , including string cosmology and astroparticle physics .

column1: What is the branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe ?
column2: Astrophysics can be studied at the bachelors , masters , and Ph.D. levels in physics or astronomy departments at many universities .

column1: What is the branch of astronomy that deals with the physics of the universe ?
column2: Many such programs retain the name " astronomy " for historical purposes .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Each club is composed of a shaft with a lance ( or " grip " ) on the top end and a club head on the bottom .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Long clubs , which have a lower amount of degreed loft , are those meant to propel the ball a comparatively longer distance , and short clubs a higher degree of loft and a comparatively shorter distance .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Typically , the actual physical length of each club is longer or shorter , depending on the distance the club is intended to propel the ball .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Golf clubs have traditionally been arranged into three basic types .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Woods are large - headed , long - shafted clubs meant to propel the ball a long distance from relatively " open " lies , such as the tee box and fairway .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Of particular importance is the " driver " or " 1 - wood " , which is the lowest lofted wood club , and in modern times has become highly specialized for making extremely long - distance tee shots , up to or more in the hands of a professional golfer .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Traditionally these clubs had heads made of a hardwood , hence the name , but virtually all modern woods are now made of metal such as titanium , or of composite materials .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Irons are shorter - shafted clubs with a metal head primarily consisting of a flat , angled striking face .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Traditionally the clubhead was forged from iron ; modern iron clubheads are investment - cast from a steel alloy .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Irons of varying loft are used for a variety of shots from virtually anywhere on the course , but most often for shorter - distance shots approaching the green , or to get the ball out of tricky lies such as sand traps .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: The third class is the putter , which evolved from the irons to create a low - lofted , balanced club designed to roll the ball along the green and into the hole .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: Putters are virtually always used on the green or in the surrounding rough / fringe .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: A fourth class , called hybrids , evolved as a cross between woods and irons , and are typically seen replacing the low - lofted irons with a club that provides similar distance , but a higher launch angle and a more forgiving nature .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: A maximum of 14 clubs is allowed in a player 's bag at one time during a stipulated round .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: The choice of clubs is at the golfer 's discretion , although every club must be constructed in accordance with parameters outlined in the rules .

column1: Describe the physical characteristics of irons .
column2: ( Clubs that meet these parameters are usually called " conforming " . )

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The response of a cancer to radiation is described by its radiosensitivity .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Highly radiosensitive cancer cells are rapidly killed by modest doses of radiation .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: These include leukemias , most lymphomas and germ cell tumors .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The majority of epithelial cancers are only moderately radiosensitive , and require a significantly higher dose of radiation ( 60-70 Gy ) to achieve a radical cure .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Some types of cancer are notably radioresistant , that is , much higher doses are required to produce a radical cure than may be safe in clinical practice .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Renal cell cancer and melanoma are generally considered to be radioresistant .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: It is important to distinguish the radiosensitivity of a particular tumor , which to some extent is a laboratory measure , from the radiation " curability " of a cancer in actual clinical practice .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: For example , leukemias are not generally curable with radiation therapy , because they are disseminated through the body .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Lymphoma may be radically curable if it is localised to one area of the body .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Similarly , many of the common , moderately radioresponsive tumors are routinely treated with curative doses of radiation therapy if they are at an early stage .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: For example : non-melanoma skin cancer , head and neck cancer , breast cancer , non-small cell lung cancer , cervical cancer , anal cancer , prostate cancer .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Metastatic cancers are generally incurable with radiation therapy because it is not possible to treat the whole body .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Before treatment , a CT scan is often performed to identify the tumor and surrounding normal structures .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The patient is then sent for a simulation so that molds can be created to be used during treatment .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The patient receives small skin marks to guide the placement of treatment fields .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The response of a tumor to radiation therapy is also related to its size .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: For complex reasons , very large tumors respond less well to radiation than smaller tumors or microscopic disease .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Various strategies are used to overcome this effect .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: The most common technique is surgical resection prior to radiation therapy .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: This is most commonly seen in the treatment of breast cancer with wide local excision or mastectomy followed by adjuvant radiation therapy .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Another method is to shrink the tumor with neoadjuvant chemotherapy prior to radical radiation therapy .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: A third technique is to enhance the radiosensitivity of the cancer by giving certain drugs during a course of radiation therapy .

column1: Can you give any examples of radiosensiting drugs ?
column2: Examples of radiosensiting drugs include : Cisplatin , Nimorazole , and Cetuximab .

column1: What happens to light that is sent down a gravity well ?

column1: What happens to light that is sent down a gravity well ?
column2: Light sent down into a gravity well is blueshifted , whereas light sent in the opposite direction ( i.e. , climbing out of the gravity well ) is redshifted ; collectively , these two effects are known as the gravitational frequency shift .

column1: What happens to light that is sent down a gravity well ?
column2: More generally , processes close to a massive body run more slowly when compared with processes taking place farther away ; this effect is known as gravitational time dilation .

column1: What happens to light that is sent down a gravity well ?

column1: What happens to light that is sent down a gravity well ?
column2: Gravitational time dilation in the Earth 's gravitational field has been measured numerous times using atomic clocks , while ongoing validation is provided as a side effect of the operation of the Global Positioning System ( GPS ) .

column1: What happens to light that is sent down a gravity well ?
column2: Tests in stronger gravitational fields are provided by the observation of binary pulsars .

column1: What happens to light that is sent down a gravity well ?
column2: All results are in agreement with general relativity .

column1: What happens to light that is sent down a gravity well ?
column2: However , at the current level of accuracy , these observations can not distinguish between general relativity and other theories in which the equivalence principle is valid .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: The Boston Tea Party ( initially referred to by John Adams as " the Destruction of the Tea in Boston " ) was a political protest by the Sons of Liberty in Boston , on December 16 , 1773 .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: Disguised as American Indians , the demonstrators destroyed an entire shipment of tea , which had been sent by the East India Company , in defiance of the Tea Act of May 10 , 1773 .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: They boarded the ships and threw the chests of tea into Boston Harbor , ruining the tea .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: The Tea Party became an iconic event of American history , and other political protests such as the Tea Party movement after 2010 explicitly refer to it .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: The Tea Party was the culmination of a resistance movement throughout British America against the Tea Act , which had been passed by the British Parliament in 1773 .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: Colonists objected to the Tea Act because they believed that it violated their rights as Englishmen to " No taxation without representation , " that is , be taxed only by their own elected representatives and not by a British parliament in which they were not represented .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: Protesters had successfully prevented the unloading of taxed tea in three other colonies , but in Boston , embattled Royal Governor Thomas Hutchinson refused to allow the tea to be returned to Britain .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: The Boston Tea Party was a key event in the growth of the American Revolution .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: Parliament responded in 1774 with the Coercive Acts , or Intolerable Acts , which , among other provisions , ended local self-government in Massachusetts and closed Boston 's commerce .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: Colonists up and down the Thirteen Colonies in turn responded to the Coercive Acts with additional acts of protest , and by convening the First Continental Congress , which petitioned the British monarch for repeal of the acts and coordinated colonial resistance to them .

column1: The demonstrators were disguised as what ?
column2: The crisis escalated , and the American Revolutionary War began near Boston in 1775 .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: The planning of radiation therapy treatment has been revolutionized by the ability to delineate tumors and adjacent normal structures in three dimensions using specialized CT and / or MRI scanners and planning software .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: Virtual simulation , the most basic form of planning , allows more accurate placement of radiation beams than is possible using conventional X-rays , where soft - tissue structures are often difficult to assess and normal tissues difficult to protect .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: An enhancement of virtual simulation is 3 - dimensional conformal radiation therapy ( 3DCRT ) , in which the profile of each radiation beam is shaped to fit the profile of the target from a beam 's eye view ( BEV ) using a multileaf collimator ( MLC ) and a variable number of beams .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: When the treatment volume conforms to the shape of the tumor , the relative toxicity of radiation to the surrounding normal tissues is reduced , allowing a higher dose of radiation to be delivered to the tumor than conventional techniques would allow .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: Intensity - modulated radiation therapy ( IMRT ) is an advanced type of high - precision radiation that is the next generation of 3DCRT .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: IMRT also improves the ability to conform the treatment volume to concave tumor shapes , for example when the tumor is wrapped around a vulnerable structure such as the spinal cord or a major organ or blood vessel .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: Computer - controlled x-ray accelerators distribute precise radiation doses to malignant tumors or specific areas within the tumor .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: The pattern of radiation delivery is determined using highly tailored computing applications to perform optimization and treatment simulation ( Treatment Planning ) .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: The radiation dose is consistent with the 3 - D shape of the tumor by controlling , or modulating , the radiation beam ’s intensity .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: The radiation dose intensity is elevated near the gross tumor volume while radiation among the neighboring normal tissue is decreased or avoided completely .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: The customized radiation dose is intended to maximize tumor dose while simultaneously protecting the surrounding normal tissue .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: This may result in better tumor targeting , lessened side effects , and improved treatment outcomes than even 3DCRT.3DCRT is still used extensively for many body sites but the use of IMRT is growing in more complicated body sites such as CNS , head and neck , prostate , breast and lung .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: Unfortunately , IMRT is limited by its need for additional time from experienced medical personnel .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: This is because physicians must manually delineate the tumors one CT image at a time through the entire disease site which can take much longer than 3DCRT preparation .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: Then , medical physicists and dosimetrists must be engaged to create a viable treatment plan .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: Both techniques enable dose escalation , potentially increasing usefulness .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: New techniques are being developed to better control this uncertainty — for example , real - time imaging combined with real - time adjustment of the therapeutic beams .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: This new technology is called image - guided radiation therapy ( IGRT ) or four - dimensional radiation therapy .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?
column2: Another technique is the real - time tracking and localization of one or more small implantable electric devices implanted inside or close to the tumor .

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?

column1: What is the limitation of IMRT technology ?

column1: Where is Times Sqaure located ?
column2: Times Square is a major commercial intersection and a neighborhood in Midtown Manhattan , New York City , at the junction of Broadway ( now converted into a pedestrian plaza ) and Seventh Avenue and stretching from West 42nd to West 47th Streets .

column2: Times Square – iconified as " The Crossroads of the World " , " The Center of the Universe " , and the " The Great White Way " – is the brightly illuminated hub of the Broadway Theater District , one of the world 's busiest pedestrian intersections , and a major center of the world 's entertainment industry .

column1: Where is Times Sqaure located ?
column2: According to " Travel + Leisure " magazine 's October 2011 survey , Times Square is the world 's most visited tourist attraction , hosting over 39 million visitors annually .

column1: Where is Times Sqaure located ?
column2: Approximately 330,000 people pass through Times Square daily , many of whom are either tourists or people working in the area .

column1: Where is Times Sqaure located ?
column2: Formerly Longacre Square , Times Square was renamed in April 1904 after " The New York Times " moved its headquarters to the newly erected Times Building – now called One Times Square – site of the annual ball drop on New Year 's Eve , a tradition which began on December 31 , 1907 and continues today , attracting thousands to the Square every New Year 's .

column1: Where is Times Sqaure located ?
column2: The northern triangle of Times Square is technically Duffy Square , dedicated in 1937 to Chaplain Francis P. Duffy of New York City 's " Fighting 69th " Infantry Regiment ; a memorial to Duffy is located there , along with a statue of George M. Cohan , and the TKTS discount theater tickets booth .

column1: Where is Times Sqaure located ?
column2: The stepped red roof of the TKTS booth also provides seating for various events .

column1: Where is Times Sqaure located ?
column2: The Duffy Statue and the square were listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2001 .

column1: Why did the American Whigs hold the belief that Parliament had no right to tax the colonies ?
column2: Controversy between Great Britain and the colonies arose in the 1760s when Parliament sought , for the first time , to impose a direct tax on the colonies for the purpose of raising revenue .

column1: Why did the American Whigs hold the belief that Parliament had no right to tax the colonies ?

column1: Why did the American Whigs hold the belief that Parliament had no right to tax the colonies ?

column1: What 's in a popcorn kernel

column1: What 's in a popcorn kernel
column2: Unlike most other grains , the outer hull of the popcorn kernel is both strong and impervious to moisture and the starch inside consists almost entirely of a hard , dense type .

column1: What 's in a popcorn kernel
column2: As the oil and the water around the kernel are heated , they turn the moisture in the kernel , which has a moisture - proof hull , into a superheated pressurized steam .

column1: What 's in a popcorn kernel
column2: Under these conditions , the starch inside the kernel gelatinizes , softens , and becomes pliable .

column1: What 's in a popcorn kernel
column2: The pressure continues to increase until the breaking point of the hull is reached : a pressure of about and a temperature of .

column1: What 's in a popcorn kernel
column2: The hull ruptures rapidly , causing a sudden drop in pressure inside the kernel and a corresponding rapid expansion of the steam , which expands the starch and proteins of the endosperm into airy foam .

column1: What 's in a popcorn kernel
column2: As the foam rapidly cools , the starch and protein polymers set into the familiar crispy puff .

column2: Special varieties are grown to give improved popping yield .

column2: Some wild types will pop , but the cultivated strain is " Zea mays everta " , which is a special kind of flint corn .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: Mutations are changes in the DNA sequence of a cell 's genome .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: When mutations occur , they can either have no effect , alter the product of a gene , or prevent the gene from functioning .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: Based on studies in the fly " Drosophila melanogaster " , it has been suggested that if a mutation changes a protein produced by a gene , this will probably be harmful , with about 70 % of these mutations having damaging effects , and the remainder being either neutral or weakly beneficial .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: Mutations can involve large sections of a chromosome becoming duplicated ( usually by genetic recombination ) , which can introduce extra copies of a gene into a genome .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: Extra copies of genes are a major source of the raw material needed for new genes to evolve .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: This is important because most new genes evolve within gene families from pre-existing genes that share common ancestors .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: For example , the human eye uses four genes to make structures that sense light : three for colour vision and one for night vision ; all four are descended from a single ancestral gene .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: New genes can be generated from an ancestral gene when a duplicate copy mutates and acquires a new function .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: This process is easier once a gene has been duplicated because it increases the redundancy of the system ; one gene in the pair can acquire a new function while the other copy continues to perform its original function .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: Other types of mutations can even generate entirely new genes from previously noncoding DNA .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: The generation of new genes can also involve small parts of several genes being duplicated , with these fragments then recombining to form new combinations with new functions .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: When new genes are assembled from shuffling pre-existing parts , domains act as modules with simple independent functions , which can be mixed together to produce new combinations with new and complex functions .

column1: Where do mutations occur ?
column2: For example , polyketide synthases are large enzymes that make antibiotics ; they contain up to one hundred independent domains that each catalyse one step in the overall process , like a step in an assembly line .

column1: Who revealed flows into the Soviet view in the October Revolution ?

column1: Who revealed flows into the Soviet view in the October Revolution ?

column1: What does every kernel of popcorn contain ?

column1: What else can someone call Olympic Weightlifting ?
column2: Olympic weightlifting , also called Olympic - style weightlifting , or weightlifting , is an athletic discipline in the modern Olympic programme in which the athlete attempts a maximum - weight single lift of a barbell loaded with weight plates .

column2: The two competition lifts in order are the snatch and the clean and jerk .

column1: What else can someone call Olympic Weightlifting ?

column1: What else can someone call Olympic Weightlifting ?

column1: What else can someone call Olympic Weightlifting ?
column2: A lifter who fails to complete at least one successful snatch and one successful clean and jerk also fails to " total " , and therefore receives an " incomplete " entry for the competition .

column1: What else can someone call Olympic Weightlifting ?
column2: The clean and press was once a competition lift , but was discontinued due to difficulties in judging proper form .

column1: What else can someone call Olympic Weightlifting ?
column2: In comparison with other strength sports , which test limit strength ( with or without lifting aids ) , Olympic weightlifting tests aspects of human ballistic limits ( explosive strength ) and are therefore executed faster — and with more mobility and a greater range of motion during their execution - than other lifts .

column1: What else can someone call Olympic Weightlifting ?
column2: Properly executed , the snatch and the clean and jerk are both dynamic and explosive while appearing graceful , especially when viewed from a recording at a slowed speed .

column1: What else can someone call Olympic Weightlifting ?
column2: While there are relatively few competitive Olympic weightlifters ( or more simply " lifters " ) , the lifts and their components are commonly used by elite athletes in other sports to train for both explosive and functional strength .

column1: What s the age of computer science ?

column1: What s the age of computer science ?
column2: In cryptography , breaking the Enigma code was an important factor contributing to the Allied victory in World War II .

column1: What s the age of computer science ?

column1: What s the age of computer science ?

column1: What s the age of computer science ?
